'''''Helvella elastica''''', commonly known as the '''flexible Helvella''',<ref name="Tylutki 1979"/> or the '''elastic saddle''',<ref name="urlRogers Mushrooms"/> is a species of [[fungi]] in the [[Helvellaceae]] family, [[Pezizales]] order. It is found in Asia, Europe, and North America. It has a roughly saddle-shaped yellow-brown [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] atop a whitish [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]], and grows on soil in woods. Another colloquial name is the '''brown elfin saddle'''.<ref name="Arora 1986"/>

== Description ==

The [[ascocarp|fruit body]] of the fungus is grayish or olive-brown, saddle- or mitral-shaped (i.e., resembling a double [[mitre]]) and is attached only to the top of the stipe; it may be up to {{convert|3|cm|in|1}} wide. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is white, solid or filled with loosely stuffed [[hyphae]], has a smooth surface, and is up to {{convert|8|cm|in|1}} long by {{convert|1|cm|in|1}} thick.<ref name="Tylutki 1979"/> The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] of ''H. elastica'' is brittle and thin. The odor and taste of this mushroom are not distinctive.<ref name="Jordan 2004"/>

===Microscopic characteristics===

The [[spore]]s are oblong to elliptical in shape, translucent ([[hyaline]]), contain one central oil drop (''guttulate''), and have dimensions of 18–22 by 10–14 [[micrometre|µm]]; young spores have coarse surface warts, while older ones are smooth. The spore-bearing cells, the [[ascus|asci]], are 260 by 17–19 µm. The [[paraphyses]] (sterile cells interspersed between the asci) are club-shaped, filled with oil drops, sometimes branched, and are 6–10 µm at the apex.<ref name="Tylutki 1979"/>

===Edibility===

Consumption of this fungus is not recommended as similar species in the [[Helvellaceae]] family contain the toxin [[gyromitrin]].<ref name="Horgen 1985"/>

== Habitat and distribution ==

This fungus is typically found fruiting singly, scattered, or clustered together on the ground or on wood in [[coniferous]] and [[deciduous]] woods.<ref name="McKnight 1987"/> It has been found in Europe,<ref name="Jordan 2004" /> North America (in "western states and provinces"),<ref name="Orr 1979"/> Japan,<ref name="Nagao 2002"/> and China.<ref name="Zhuang 2004"/>

== Similar species ==

The closely related fungus ''[[Helvella albipes]]'' has a thicker stipe and a two- to four-lobed cap.<ref name="Tylutki 1979"/> Another similar species, ''[[Helvella latispora|H. latispora]]'', has cap edges that are curled upward, rather than inward as in ''H. elastica''.<ref name="urlHelvella elastica (MushroomExpert.Com)"/>

== Fibrinolytic activity ==

A 2005 Korean study investigated the ability of extracts from 67 different mushroom species to perform [[fibrinolysis]], the process of breaking down [[blood clot]]s caused by the protein [[fibrin]]. ''H. elastica'' was one of seven species that had this ability; the activity of the extract was 60% of that of [[plasmin]], the [[scientific control|positive control]] used in the experiment.<ref name="Kim 2005"/>
